children.value: Nuxt Custom-Elements allows you to export your existing project components as custom elements for integration into external pages.
Use TailwindCSS and Vuetify for your widgets

contents.title: Setup
contents.description: Check the Nuxt.js documentation for more information about installing and using modules in Nuxt.js.

contents.title: Usage
contents.description: Nuxt Custom-Elements is used to export components from a Nuxt.js project as custom elements, this is used when providing widgets.

children.value: Nuxt Custom-Elements is used to export components from a
project as custom elements, this is used when providing widgets.

as a custom element. Alternatively, you can take a look at the

in Vue. For the local Vue instance the respective tag is unknown.
::

props.code:
<script>

import Vue from 'vue';

Vue.config.ignoredElements = [
  'custom-element-example'
];

export default {
  created () {
    this.$customElements.registerEntry('Example')
  }
}
</script>

children.value: Place the relevant tags in a

The Webpack Public Path is important for the integration of a custom element entry on an external page.
It defines from which origin the resources (fonts, images, scripts) should be loaded.
Normally this Public Path is located at
, if I include an entry externally, all resources on the external page will be loaded.
To solve this, the build must be told what the correct Public Path is.
is included, so the public path must also be defined with this url as root.
The modification can be done in two ways:
Define fixed public path in the build
For a fixed definition of the publich path, the
option must be extended in the entry in
Alternatively, the public path can be set dynamically in the

props.code:
<custom-element-example />

<script type="text/javascript">
  window.externalPublicPath = 'https://<your-domain>/custom-elements/my-entry';
</script>

<script src="https://<your-domain>/custom-elements/my-entry/my-entry.js"></script>

you can find configurations for the examples.

children.value: is used to include the defined entries during development.
This allows you to include the components without a separate import and allows you to test as a custom-elements integration.
. After registration it is possible to call the custom-element tags in the template. Only the tags that have been added to the entry are available.

Nuxt Custom-Elements allows you to export your existing project components as custom elements for integration into external pages.

contents.title: Setup
contents.description: Check the Nuxt.js documentation for more information about installing and using modules in Nuxt.js.

children.value: for more information about installing and using modules in Nuxt.js.

props.code: yarn add nuxt-custom-elements@beta
npm install nuxt-custom-elements@beta

children.value: Components can be distributed in separate endpoints.
Allows the targeted distribution of resources.
Name of the endpoint. Value will be converted to ParamCase later.
and allows to customize the configuration before build.
and allows to customize the configuration before build.
* Defines the webpack optimization options, see [webpack optimization](https://webpack.js.org/configuration/optimization/).
* Example to create several chunks with minimum size of 100kb.
* One of the chunks contains all vue and vuetify related vendor libraries:
Name of the Tag. Value will be converted to ParamCase later.
Components are loaded asynchronously. If there is more than one entry the async will lead to unwanted webpack chunk splitting.
Path to the component to be called by the tag.

With this setting the components are used as CustomElement during runtime (Dev/Server) and incorrect views may occur.
